seo.meta_title: Mount Mansfield Trail Guide | 5 Routes, Maps & Conditions
seo.meta_description: Plan your Mount Mansfield hike with live conditions, 5 trail maps & parking info. NH 4000-Footer at 4,393 ft.

schema_place.name: Mount Mansfield
schema_place.description: Mount Mansfield is a 4,393 foot peak in Vermont offering hiking trails with scenic views.

mainEntity.name: How long does it take to hike Mount Mansfield?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most routes on Mount Mansfield take 3-5 hours round trip. The most popular trail is 6.4 miles with Hard difficulty. Start early, especially on weekends when parking fills quickly.

mainEntity.name: Is Mount Mansfield hard to hike?

acceptedAnswer.text: Mount Mansfield is rated Hard. At 4,393 feet, expect challenging terrain above treeline with potential for rapid weather changes. Proper footwear and preparation are essential.

mainEntity.name: Do I need a permit to hike Mount Mansfield?

acceptedAnswer.text: No hiking permit is required for Mount Mansfield. However, parking fees may apply at trailheads (typically $3-5/day for WMNF or state parks). A WMNF parking pass covers most White Mountain trailheads.

mainEntity.name: What is the best trail to hike Mount Mansfield?

acceptedAnswer.text: The most popular route is the Sunset Ridge Trail, offering Spectacular open ridge with panoramic views. Most scenic route to the Chin..

mainEntity.name: When is the best time to hike Mount Mansfield?

acceptedAnswer.text: The best hiking season for Mount Mansfield is late May through October. Summer and fall offer the best conditions, though expect crowds on weekends. Winter hiking requires specialized gear and experience.

page_content.description:
At 4,393 feet, Mount Mansfield ranks among New Hampshire's celebrated 4000-Footers—a collection of 48 peaks that challenge and inspire hikers throughout the Northeast. This hard summit offers a quintessential White Mountain experience.

Popular Routes

The most popular route, **Sunset Ridge Trail**, covers 6.4 miles and is rated Hard. Spectacular open ridge with panoramic views. Most scenic route to the Chin.

Peak Bagging

This peak offers a standalone hiking experience with minimal nearby alternatives.

spring.title: Spring Conditions
spring.conditions: Muddy trails, snow above 3000ft until May
spring.tips: Trail closures for mud season (April-May). Check conditions before heading out.

summer.title: Summer Conditions
summer.tips: Start early to avoid afternoon storms and parking issues. Peak crowds on weekends.

fall.title: Fall Conditions
fall.conditions: Peak foliage late Sept, early snow possible in October
fall.tips: Peak foliage brings peak crowds. Weekday hikes recommended. Watch for ice above treeline in late October.

winter.title: Winter Conditions
winter.conditions: Full winter conditions, extreme cold and wind above treeline
winter.tips: Winter hiking requires specialized skills and gear. Never hike alone. Check avalanche conditions for steeper terrain.

current_hazards: ⚠️ ALPINE ZONE: Weather changes rapidly. Turn back if conditions deteriorate.
Winter conditions in effect - full mountaineering gear required
Hypothermia risk - temperatures 20-40°F colder at summit
Trail markers may be buried under snow
